Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: The City University of New York / Goddard Institute for Space Studies Center for Global Climate Research Phase II
Award.AbstractNarration:
The City University of New York (CUNY)/Goddard Institute for Space Studies (GISS) Center for Global Climate Research (CGCR), is based on research related to Geoscience, Atmospheric Science, Sun-Earth interaction and Global Climate Impacts. CUNY/GISS CGCR-Phase II will continue to provide this unique undergraduate student research experience for a second three-year period. Each Summer, ten students will be recruited in the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site and will be distributed among the research teams (five at CUNY, five at GISS) under the mentorship of CUNY faculty and NASA scientists. Students will receive a stipend for 10 weeks of research experience. In addition to recruiting students from four-year colleges, the proposed activities will continue to include an active recruitment of students at the community college level. Student external to CUNY, in greater NYC Region, are also encouraged to apply. The CUNY/GISS REU Site will continue to seek 60% under-represented minorities and 40% female participation each year. The Objectives are to: a)provide undergraduate summer research opportunities in Global Climate Change and related areas at CUNY and GISS to a larger Greater NYC region constituency; b)provide enrichment activities at GISS and CUNY which include basic technical skills workshops and
seminars; c)assist students in continuing their research during the academic year, leveraging existing NASA, NSF and NOAA programs; and d)increase the number of students in the STEM pathway to graduate school and to the scientific workforce.

Intellectual Merit :
Students will be involved in existing research projects which are collaborations with NASA scientists and CUNY faculty funded by NASA and/or NOAA. Students will be engaged in original research and contributing to the general body of knowledge in Global Climate Change. The collaboration occurs within a small urban geographical area, which enables faculty and students to interact with scientists on daily basis. The faculty, students and scientists have developed a unique relationship that has benefited both CUNY and NASA GISS.

Broader Impacts :
This unique urban CUNY-GISS collaboration was expanded so that more undergraduate students in CUNY and the Greater New York City Region could experience the rich scientific research and the diversity of the melting pot environment of CUNY/GISS. Students are involved in cutting edge research, access to a NASA research center and have the opportunity of presenting their results at national conferences and as co-authors in peered review publications. The CUNY faculty and GISS scientists collaboration has a track record of working with students that are under-represented in STEM areas and advancing student through the STEM pathway to graduate study in areas in which fewer students are selecting as careers and where the loss of retired scientists is significant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
REU Site: The City University of New York (CUNY) / Goddard Institute for Space Studies (GISS) Center for Global Climate Research (CGCR) Phase II provided undergraduate students a research experience related to Geoscience, Atmospheric Science, Space Weather, Global Climate Impacts, Planetary Atmospheres and Space Technology (nanosatellites). The CUNY/GISS CGCR Phase II enhanced the collaboration between NASA GISS and CUNY by creating additional Summer and Academic Year research opportunities and enrichment experiences for undergraduate science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) majors in the greater New York City Region.

Ten or more students were selected for the program each summer and academic year and they participated in research teams at CUNY or GISS. In addition to recruiting students from four-year colleges, we actively recruited students at the community college level, since community colleges have a large neglected pool of interested STEM students. This emphasis stems from successful experiences by CUNY faculty and GISS scientists involved in this REU Site in moving students through the community college to senior college to the graduate school research pathway. Students external to CUNY, in greater NYC Region, were also encouraged to apply.  As a result, a total of 41 students participated in REU projects, with 32 from CUNY colleges and 9 from external universities including Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Florida Institute of Technology, Colby College, Polytechnic Institute of New York University, SUNY-Albany, Pennsylvania State University, New York University, SUNY –Binghamton, and SUNY– Stony Brook. Twelve students were from CUNY community college when they began their research before transferring to senior colleges. 

For the period 2014-2017, 59 percent of the participants were underrepresented minorities and 34 percent were female. This reflects the track record of a long collaboration between CUNY faculty and GISS scientists working with students that are underrepresented in STEM areas and advancing students through the STEM pathway to graduate study and the STEM workforce in areas in which fewer students are selecting as careers and where the loss of retired scientists is significant.

Students were involved in cutting edge research, had access to a NASA research center and had the opportunity of presenting their results at national conferences and as co-authors in peered review publications. Participating students were provided workshops and seminars for developing professional skills, research background and promoting collegiality among the teams. Workshops were hosted by GISS and CUNY campuses, as well as a field center in the New York State Adirondacks. Annual summer workshops also included Technical Writing and Ethics in Science.  All students were required to present posters at annual CUNY-wide Summer Student Research Summits in collaboration with the NSF, NASA, CUNY and regional programs. In addition, students were required to submit a final written report on their research project.  Students have given 25 papers or poster presentations at regional or national conferences.

Research topics include:

• Analysis of El Niño-Southern Oscillation Phenomena’s Effect on the Gross Domestic Product of Western Pacific Nations                                                        

• Wetland Carbon Project 2014                                                                          

• Evaluation of RM3 Weather Forecasts Over Western Africa During the 2013 Summer Monsoon                                                                                                  

• Sunscreen for the City: Using White Roofs to Combat the Urban Heat Island Effect            

• The Impact of Climate Change on Hurricane Energy  

• Modeling and Analysis of possible strikes of Geomagnetic Disturbance (GMD) on the New York Power Grid 

• Assessing ocean vertical mixing schemes for the study of climate change

• D-Photochemical Modeling of the Martian Atmosphere: Seasonal Variations,

• Intelligent Systems for Nanosatellites

• Habitat Space on a Snowball Earth: Understanding Life on the Outer Edge of the Habitable Zone

• Use of Sudden Ionospheric Disturbance Monitors to Detect Coronal Mass Ejections  

• Creating an Arctic Gridded Data Set that Reflects Temporal and Spatial Distributions of Oxygen Isotopic Compositions of Seawater 

• Characterizing Interplanetary Structures of Long-Lasting Ionospheric Storm Events: Modeling the Dst Parameter

• Chemical Pathway Analysis of the Martian Atmosphere: The Formation and Destruction of Ozone

• Tropospheric Ozone Investigations in Urban and Rural areas

Overall, the REU was a positive experience for participating students. Survey data indicated that students gained research skills and confidence in their ability to participate in research. Student outcomes provided further evidence given the number of students in graduate school or planning to attend. We believe that is due to the dedication and contributions from NASA GISS scientists mentors and CUNY faculty mentors.
